name: 寫作指導（二）
restrict: ◎限大一修習◎必須先修過【ENU0237  寫作指導（一）】
description: This two-semester course is to help students develop their ability to properly express themselves in written English. In the first semester, students are expected to acquire the fundamentals of English paragraph-writing, including structure (topic sentence, controlling idea, support and conclusion), outline, organization and coherence. In the second semester, students will extend their one-paragraph writing skills to three-paragraph short-essay writing. In addition, this course aims to equip students with analytic writing competence in response to different scenarios. In particular, course assignments will cover intensive writing practices in different modes, including description, narration, process, cause-effect, comparison-contrast, definition, and classification.
goals: This class is to help students improve their skills in writing English paragraphs/essays.

**Course Objective**

        This course has two main purposes: to provide a workshop for enrolled students to develop basic writing skills, and to offer an opportunity to brush up English grammar. Since writing is both personal and social, students should learn how to write for a variety of purposes and audiences. Classes rely heavily on a workshop format. Instruction emphasizes the connection between writing, reading, and critical thinking. Students should give thoughtful responses to the readings through well-versed writings. Both reading and writing are the subject of class discussions and workshops, and students are expected to be active participants of the classroom community. Students will have many opportunities to share their work with others. We will examine individuals’ writing processes and pay particular attention to paragraph practice. Altogether 4 pieces of composition are to be fulfilled this semester.

**Course Requirements**

1.  Thoughtful, active, and responsible participation and citizenship, including oral discussion, preparation for class, in-class writing.
2.  5 papers, edited and polished. (100%; 20% each).
3.  All drafts must be typed, double-spaced 12pt Times New Roman. On the top left corner of the first page please include your name, student number, and date.
4.  Compositions should be turned in in due time. No late papers are allowed.
5.  Attendance is a very important part of the requirement—in excess of 3 absences is grounds for failure.
6.  Composition grades will be determined by ideas, diction, grammar, spelling, and development.

1.  Content (50 %): main ideas, argument, supporting evidence, diction, etc.
2.  Mechanics (50 %): grammar, spelling, punctuation, format, etc.

7.  Plagiarism is grounds for failure in this course. It will not be tolerated.

**Required Texts**

Sullivan, Kathleen E. _Paragraph Practice_. New York: Macmillan, 1994.

Langan, John. _Paragraph Skills_. 2nd ed. New York: McGraw-Hill, 2010.
